.BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 23, 1921
A TRIBUTE TO FRANCE AND MARSHAL FOCH
In conferring the degree of Doctor of Laws upon Marshal Foch,
Johns Hopkins University paid tribute to our sister republic across
the sea and to the foremost general of the age. The act of the University was another recognition of the great debt which we owe to
our allies and which it will be impossible to repay for years to come.
It is particularly appropriate that this tribute should have been
made through the medium of Marshal Foch, who lead the allied
armies to victory. His presence upon our campus will long be remembered and yesterday will go down in the annals of the present
undergraduate body as a red-lettered day.
THE STATE CHAMPIONSHIP
For the first time in several years Johns Hopkins will be able to
close the football season with the title "Champions of the State of
Maryland" after its name. Pleasanter still is the realization of the
fact that the claim is clear-cut, undisputed and respected by all.
But now that the honor is ours, let us not forget to place the
credit where credit is due.
First and foremost, too much credit cannot be given to Coaches
Van Orman and O'Rourke, whose untiring efforts of two years finally
accomplished the results which others were unable to obtain.
Captain Bill Totterdale deserves a world of praise for the morale
with which he kept his mates instilled. To the team itself, of course,
goes our unanimous vote of appreciation. Lacking individual stars,
it has played a steady fighting machinelike game throughout its schedule.
One of the most deserving elements, but one which generally
slips the mind of the enthusiastic rooter, is the forgotten, maltreated
individual ordinarily dignified by the name "Scrub." Those reserves
who daily gave their time and energies that a winning outfit might
be produced should share honors equally with the "first team."
Last but not least, the team owes its success to the generous
support of those never-tiring, loyal rooters who followed the squad
in its defeats and its victories, lending their lungs as a bolster to
courage.
Without any one of these elements, the team would not have
succeeded so well. To team work on and off the field we owe our
success.
OTHERS TO WHOM CREDIT IS DUE
The old Black and Blue eleven did itself proud last Saturday
and we feel that they are directly responsible for that satisfied smile
which has been so much in evidence on the campus this week. To
the student body at large may be attributed a spirit which would be
hard to duplicate in any other college in the country. F-7ery one did
their part and helped to consummate the victory of the season. It is
appropriate that an appreciation of special value should be voted to
some whose efforts have shown them to be worthy of special comment. Those committees who made arrangements for the various
events are to be complimented on the excellence of their work. The
efforts of a smiling corps of ushers brought cheer on a gloomy afternoon.
The students owe their thanks to Major Garey and his staff, on
account of their whole-hearted co-operation. And last, but far from
least, much credit is due to Gilson Engel for his spirited work as a
cheer leader and organizer and also to his assistants, Joe Thompson
and Don Vanneman. Without the hearty aid of all these loyal supporters of Johnny Hopkins it might have been a different story.
ANNOUNCEMENT
On account of the Thanksgiving holiday the present issue of the
News-Letter is appearing Wednesday, and the next issue will not
appear until Thursday, December first.

DR. BRIDGMAN'S LETTER
It is with great pleasure that the News-Letter publishes Dr.
Bridgeman's letter on the Varsity Club. We believe that co-operation between the Varsity Club and the undergraduate body is necessary and that the best way that this co-operation can be obtained is
by perfect and complete understanding on both sides. It is to be
hoped that the undergraduate members of the club and the representatives to the Holding Company will take an active interest in
these organizations.
The Varsity Club exists solely for the good of the University
and has already accomplished a great deal. We extend it our heartiest
congratulations and express our willingness to be called upon at any
time for any aid within our power.

MR. PLUMB ADDRESSES SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB
Outlines Plumb Plan and Answers Questions. Mr. Fenneman Explains the
Purposes of the Club.

Mr. Plumb, originator of the

Y. M. C. A. ACTIVITIES

The Deputation Team started
work Sunday, at Easton M. E.
Church, near Ananpolis. The team
is expected to visit a church each
Sunday and will make several trips
around the city. It is made up of
Henry Callard, '24, chairman; Leroy Baughman, '22; Paul Stevens,
'23, and William Roberts, '24. An
invitation was extended to those
who wish to be on the team, and if
enough men are obtained another
team will be formed. Callard did
fine work last year and it is expected that he will be one of the
best chairmen that Hopkins has
had.
A few weeks ago a conference
was held at the Central Branch,
Cathedral and Franklin Streets, on
student delegates from the colleges
of Maryland, in the interest of the
Student Friendship Fund. About
twenty colleges were represented,
and they drew up a resolution to
put in a campaign for said fund on
the various college campuses.

HARRY KING TOOTLE,'03,
VISITS THE UNIVERSITY
Alumnus Envies the Good Fortune of
the College Men Who Have
Homewood.

Harry King Tootle, '03, paid his
first visit to Homewood last Monday since the war. Before going
abroad he had made occasional
tripS to the University from Camp
Meade, where he was stationed for
a time. Mr. Tootle now spends
most of the year on his country
place, near Bethany, W. Va. He
was in Baltimore to see two new
plays here before they reached the
metropolis. His interest in the
theatrical world is due to the fact
that he is himself a playright.
"Cheated," his first play written
since the Nvar, had its successful
stock tryout last summer, and Mr.
Tootle visited Baltimore on his way
to New York to arrange for its
Broadway production when theatrical conditions improve.

Plumb Plan and well known in industrial circles as an advocate of
a square deal for everyone, addressed the Social Science Club last
Wednesday.
In presenting his speech, Mr.
Plumb went back to the early government and the Bill of Rights that
was formulated to protect each citizen in his liberties. From this bill,
he claims that the American people get three great industrial principles. First, that the government
is for the common good of all and
not for the interest of a small and
favored class. Second, that no man,
corporation or group of men can
get more for a service than is fair
to the public. Third, that men have
the right to enjoy the gains their
industry produces. These three
principles are violated in their entirety by the modern corporation,

.BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 23, 1921
A TRIBUTE TO FRANCE AND MARSHAL FOCH
In conferring the degree of Doctor of Laws upon Marshal Foch,
Johns Hopkins University paid tribute to our sister republic across
the sea and to the foremost general of the age. The act of the University was another recognition of the great debt which we owe to
our allies and which it will be impossible to repay for years to come.
It is particularly appropriate that this tribute should have been
made through the medium of Marshal Foch, who lead the allied
armies to victory. His presence upon our campus will long be remembered and yesterday will go down in the annals of the present
undergraduate body as a red-lettered day.
THE STATE CHAMPIONSHIP
For the first time in several years Johns Hopkins will be able to
close the football season with the title "Champions of the State of
Maryland" after its name. Pleasanter still is the realization of the
fact that the claim is clear-cut, undisputed and respected by all.
But now that the honor is ours, let us not forget to place the
credit where credit is due.
First and foremost, too much credit cannot be given to Coaches
Van Orman and O'Rourke, whose untiring efforts of two years finally
accomplished the results which others were unable to obtain.
Captain Bill Totterdale deserves a world of praise for the morale
with which he kept his mates instilled. To the team itself, of course,
goes our unanimous vote of appreciation. Lacking individual stars,
it has played a steady fighting machinelike game throughout its schedule.
One of the most deserving elements, but one which generally
slips the mind of the enthusiastic rooter, is the forgotten, maltreated
individual ordinarily dignified by the name "Scrub." Those reserves
who daily gave their time and energies that a winning outfit might
be produced should share honors equally with the "first team."
Last but not least, the team owes its success to the generous
support of those never-tiring, loyal rooters who followed the squad
in its defeats and its victories, lending their lungs as a bolster to
courage.
Without any one of these elements, the team would not have
succeeded so well. To team work on and off the field we owe our
success.
OTHERS TO WHOM CREDIT IS DUE
The old Black and Blue eleven did itself proud last Saturday
and we feel that they are directly responsible for that satisfied smile
which has been so much in evidence on the campus this week. To
the student body at large may be attributed a spirit which would be
hard to duplicate in any other college in the country. F-7ery one did
their part and helped to consummate the victory of the season. It is
appropriate that an appreciation of special value should be voted to
some whose efforts have shown them to be worthy of special comment. Those committees who made arrangements for the various
events are to be complimented on the excellence of their work. The
efforts of a smiling corps of ushers brought cheer on a gloomy afternoon.
The students owe their thanks to Major Garey and his staff, on
account of their whole-hearted co-operation. And last, but far from
least, much credit is due to Gilson Engel for his spirited work as a
cheer leader and organizer and also to his assistants, Joe Thompson
and Don Vanneman. Without the hearty aid of all these loyal supporters of Johnny Hopkins it might have been a different story.
ANNOUNCEMENT
On account of the Thanksgiving holiday the present issue of the
News-Letter is appearing Wednesday, and the next issue will not
appear until Thursday, December first.

DR. BRIDGMAN'S LETTER
It is with great pleasure that the News-Letter publishes Dr.
Bridgeman's letter on the Varsity Club. We believe that co-operation between the Varsity Club and the undergraduate body is necessary and that the best way that this co-operation can be obtained is
by perfect and complete understanding on both sides. It is to be
hoped that the undergraduate members of the club and the representatives to the Holding Company will take an active interest in
these organizations.
The Varsity Club exists solely for the good of the University
and has already accomplished a great deal. We extend it our heartiest
congratulations and express our willingness to be called upon at any
time for any aid within our power.

MR. PLUMB ADDRESSES SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB
Outlines Plumb Plan and Answers Questions. Mr. Fenneman Explains the
Purposes of the Club.

Mr. Plumb, originator of the

Y. M. C. A. ACTIVITIES

The Deputation Team started
work Sunday, at Easton M. E.
Church, near Ananpolis. The team
is expected to visit a church each
Sunday and will make several trips
around the city. It is made up of
Henry Callard, '24, chairman; Leroy Baughman, '22; Paul Stevens,
'23, and William Roberts, '24. An
invitation was extended to those
who wish to be on the team, and if
enough men are obtained another
team will be formed. Callard did
fine work last year and it is expected that he will be one of the
best chairmen that Hopkins has
had.
A few weeks ago a conference
was held at the Central Branch,
Cathedral and Franklin Streets, on
student delegates from the colleges
of Maryland, in the interest of the
Student Friendship Fund. About
twenty colleges were represented,
and they drew up a resolution to
put in a campaign for said fund on
the various college campuses.

HARRY KING TOOTLE,'03,
VISITS THE UNIVERSITY
Alumnus Envies the Good Fortune of
the College Men Who Have
Homewood.

Harry King Tootle, '03, paid his
first visit to Homewood last Monday since the war. Before going
abroad he had made occasional
tripS to the University from Camp
Meade, where he was stationed for
a time. Mr. Tootle now spends
most of the year on his country
place, near Bethany, W. Va. He
was in Baltimore to see two new
plays here before they reached the
metropolis. His interest in the
theatrical world is due to the fact
that he is himself a playright.
"Cheated," his first play written
since the Nvar, had its successful
stock tryout last summer, and Mr.
Tootle visited Baltimore on his way
to New York to arrange for its
Broadway production when theatrical conditions improve.

Plumb Plan and well known in industrial circles as an advocate of
a square deal for everyone, addressed the Social Science Club last
Wednesday.
In presenting his speech, Mr.
Plumb went back to the early government and the Bill of Rights that
